section.title: Making predictions
section.sectiontitle: We often use the adverbs definitely, almost certainly, probably + will + verb to show how certain we are about something happening.
section.text1a: I think he'll almost certainly pass the exam.
section.text2a: Our team will probably lose on Saturday.
section.text3a: We definitely won't be there on time.

section.title: Making predictions
section.sectiontitle: We use the modal verbs may, might, could to say that something is possible in the future. We add well if we are more certain it will happen.
section.text1: It is possible that it will rain tomorrow.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use may not and might not. We don't use short forms. We don't use could not to talk about the future.

section.title: Making predictions
section.sectiontitle: We use is likely to when we think something will probably happen. In the negative, we use is not likely to.
section.text1a: People are likely to live longer in the next century.
